capitalism.view.custom

Enum ActionStates

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<ActionStates>
      • capitalism.view.custom.ActionStates
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<ActionStates>

    public enum ActionStates
extends java.lang.Enum<ActionStates>
    This class is central to the operation of the simulation. It defines the possible actions of the simulation, which are of two types: (1) sub-actions such as Demand which carry out primitive actions;(2) super-actions such as Exchange which conducts a series of primitive actions. The super-Actions correspond to normal economic phases or 'aspects' of the reproduction of an economy namely the purchase of commodities, the production of commodities, and the distribution of revenues. The primitives don't have a distinct economic meaning but can help understand the logical components of a complete economic activity. This is given visual representation at several places in the simulation, notably in the logfile and in the actionButtons, which have a tree structure so that the user may decide either to study the detail of a phase or simply the it overall effects.

    • Field Detail

      • nextAction

        protected ActionStates nextAction
        the nextAction will be a primitive action if this is a primitive action (eg after Supply we have to do Demand). if this is a superAction such as PreTrade, the nextAction is the next superAction

      • firstSubAction

        protected ActionStates firstSubAction
        if this is a superAction such as M_C, the nextAction is the next superAction. But in that case we must also know the next permissible primitive action, which is a component of this superAction (eg registerSupply is the firstSubAction of M-C)

      • text

        protected java.lang.String text
        the text to be used on this actionState's button. Also used to serialise it in the Project persistent entity

      • command

        private Command command
        the command that will be executed when this button is pressed

      • tooltip

        protected java.lang.String tooltip
        the tooltip associated with the button that carries out this action

      • isSubState

        protected boolean isSubState
        true if this is a substate, false if it is a superstate

      • superAction

        public ActionStates superAction
        if this is a subState, superAction says what its superAction is TODO not needed I think

      • superActionAsInteger

        protected int superActionAsInteger
        an integer representation of superAction TODO store the superAction directly into the database?

      • setSuccessor

        public void setSuccessor(ActionStates nextAction)
        define the successor of this action. Normal usage would be (1) if this is a subAction which has a successor subAction, this would be the nextAction (2) if this is the last SubAction in the current superAction, the nextAction of this would be the next SuperAction (3) if this is a superAction,the nextAction would be the next SuperAction.
        Parameters:
        nextAction - the nextAction

      • setPermissibleSubAction

        public void setPermissibleSubAction(ActionStates subAction)
        if this action has a permissible subAction (the first in the list of its components) make a note, so the corresponding button can be enabled
        Parameters:
        subAction - the next permissible subAction, if there is one (otherwise, don't call this method!)

      • setParent

        public void setParent(ActionStates superAction)
        if this is a subAction, this defines its parent. This is used to place the subAction in the tree under the appropriate superAction
        Parameters:
        superAction - the parent superAction
